title: 'Pandemonium' hits as fox hunt sees "screaming hounds" invade quiet street and back garden to chase animal
text:
'Pandemonium' hits as fox hunt sees "screaming hounds" invade quiet street and back garden to chase animal Neighbours were too frightened and shaken to come out of their homes during the mayhem Share Residents say a pack of foxhounds caused mayhem in a quiet road in Macclesfield (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! A fox hunt was described as 'pandemonium' after residents claimed a pack of "screaming" foxhounds chased a fox through a quiet street and into a private garden. 
Frightened residents said they were too shocked to come out of their homes during the mayhem, and elderly people living in Pennington Lane, in Macclesfield, Cheshire, were left terrified. 
There were reports of 15 dogs hurtling through a field with pregnant animals, and into a road and garden during the hunt on Saturday. Cheshire Police are now investigating the allegations. 
“It was horrific”, Edwina Church, 47, told the MEN . 
She said her husband, Kevin, saw some of the dogs appear to be chasing a fox which he then saw killed. 
She added: “Pandemonium broke out. There was a stream of dogs running through our garden into next door. We had 15 of them jumping around in our garden.” 
Edwina's 82-year-old mother, who has chronic heart failure, saw the incident unfold and is said to be “traumatised”. Residents claimed pandemonium broke out as a pack of "screaming" foxhounds chased a fox through a quiet street (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Edwina added:“A lot of people on this road are elderly. They were frightened to come out. The dogs were frantic. I’m an animal-lover and I was shaken. It was heartbreaking.” Read More 
People living on the road said they heard a “screaming” pack of dogs belonging to Cheshire Forest Hunt run through nearby fields where pregnant cows were grazing at around 12.45pm on Saturday. 
Two quad bikes then came “flying down the lane” said resident Julie Clark, 47. 
Edwina claims one of the hunt members got off her bike and retrieved the dead fox from the garden. 
Other members of the hunt then arrived together with the police. A group of foxhounds reportedly chased a fox down a quiet street (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Julie said:“The dogs were huge. God knows how someone didn’t get hurt. It was dreadful.” 
Farmer Andrew Kidd had pregnant heifers in a field where the dog rampaged. He said Cheshire Forest Hunt Huntsmaster Richard Garton phoned him after the incident. 
Andrew claimed the huntsmaster “apologised 100%”. Read More Fox eaten alive by hunting dogs after being chased in sickening footage filmed by animal rights activists 
Macclesfield Councillor Beverley Dooley said permission had not been given for the hunt to cross the land. 
She said: “It’s beyond me. Penningtons Lane is used by people walking dogs, by children on bikes. There were no children playing in the gardens when it happened. “ 
“We’re all shocked at the blatant disregard for other people and their property - their land, their animals.” 
A statement from Cheshire Police confirmed the force was investigating he incident. 
It added: "A fox has been recovered and officers are continuing to obtain evidence to enable them to investigate this thoroughly." 
Superintendent Pete Crowcroft said: “The Constabulary takes allegations of any illegal activity seriously and we have specialist officers working with the RSPCA on the investigation. 
"I understand the residents who witnessed the events were left distressed and I want to reassure them that we are thoroughly investigating matters. Any incident that causes concern in our communities is a priority to us and we have sent local officers to the community to speak with residents and help with reassurance. 
"When the police investigation is complete we will work with the CPS to consider the evidence. And the police investigation is being supervised by a senior officer. 
"As with all investigations we seek to gather all the information and evidence so we can to try and fully establish what has happened. 
"Anyone with information should contact Cheshire Police on 101 quoting incident number 395 of 25 February 2017." 
Mirror Online has contacted Cheshire Forest Hunt for a comment. Like us on Facebook
